head.title: Second Sightings: Eight Wish Lists; Copenhagen

hedline.hl1: Second Sightings: Eight Wish Lists; Copenhagen

abstract.p: Anita Gates comment on Copenhagen as place where she suddenly likes herring, and as favorite destination on her travel wish list (special section, The Sophisticated Traveler) (part 2 of 2-part section) (S)

block.p: I want to go back to Copenhagen, soon, and not just because there's an amusement park in the middle of town. Tivoli is a drawing card, of course. It has gardens, elegant restaurants, fireworks displays and a wooden roller coaster so old that no sane adult would board it unless he or she had had a few too many aquavits beforehand. (Of course, that sort of thing does happen.)

Other strange things happen to me in Copenhagen, especially in restaurants. Suddenly I like herring. Suddenly it seems perfectly normal to spread mustard, rather than butter, on my bread. And I almost like beer. I want to go back to Copenhagen and practice saying ''skol'' properly (the vowel rhymes with the one in Ma and Pa, I'm told). I want to go back to the Hotel d'Angleterre at teatime to ask the waitress again for coffee and a Danish and have her ask, ''A Danish what?'' I want to have a leisurely dinner at 9 P.M. in June and take a walk afterward -- in twilight.

I want to go back to Copenhagen, soon, and not just because there's an amusement park in the middle of town. Tivoli is a drawing card, of course. It has gardens, elegant restaurants, fireworks displays and a wooden roller coaster so old that no sane adult would board it unless he or she had had a few too many aquavits beforehand. (Of course, that sort of thing does happen.)

Other strange things happen to me in Copenhagen, especially in restaurants. Suddenly I like herring. Suddenly it seems perfectly normal to spread mustard, rather than butter, on my bread. And I almost like beer. I want to go back to Copenhagen and practice saying ''skol'' properly (the vowel rhymes with the one in Ma and Pa, I'm told). I want to go back to the Hotel d'Angleterre at teatime to ask the waitress again for coffee and a Danish and have her ask, ''A Danish what?'' I want to have a leisurely dinner at 9 P.M. in June and take a walk afterward -- in twilight.

In Denmark you're never more than 10 minutes away from a castle or at least from a Hans-Christian-Andersen-slept-here anecdote. If you ever looked at storybook illustrations as a child, you will have, I predict, visceral reactions to seeing the real-life moats and turrets and swans of fairy tales. I don't know why people keep knocking the head off the Little Mermaid's statue, but it's probably the single least interesting Andersen attraction anyway.

Most important, though, I need to go back to Copenhagen's pedestrian shopping street, the Stroget, and get a ridiculously expensive down comforter. The one I had shipped home in 1985 is finally showing signs of wear, but it's still light as marshmallows, warm as toast. The Danes really know how to sleep.
Editor in the Arts and Leisure section of The Times.
